Situation1: They conduct an in-depth consultation with a patient taking multiple high-risk medications to prevent dangerous interactions.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pharmacy wall, feeling the weight of the afternoon pressing in. My habit was hidden beneath my white coat, a silent reminder of the life I led outside these walls. Today, I had promised myself a rare, uninterrupted afternoon for spiritual reading and reflection—a time to reconnect with God, to nourish my soul as a nun. But just as I was about to leave, Mrs. Alvarez arrived, clutching a paper bag of new prescriptions. Her chart showed a tangle of high-risk medications, each with the potential to harm if not managed carefully. As a pharmacist, I knew I couldn’t let her leave without a thorough consultation. My duty was clear: ensure her safety, explain every interaction, answer every question. Yet, my heart ached for the quiet chapel, the open Bible, the peace I’d been longing for all week. The expectations of my two worlds collided inside me—one demanding my presence for healing of the body, the other calling me to tend to my spirit. I stood at the counter, torn, the weight of both vocations heavy on my shoulders.
